content.LoanOverlayFE_ActualCostofLoantextLoanMo: The money you pay your loan back with will come from your income after taxes have been taken out. Keep in mind that you'll also have to pay the interest, so in other words you'll be double-taxed, which defeats the purpose of having a tax-deferred account.<br/><br/> Check out the details of your plan and/or loan terms to find out if you're eligible for a loan and the fees for borrowing.<br/><br/>

content.LoanOverlayFE_RetirementIncomeImpacthead: How does taking out a loan affect my retirement income?
content.HelpText_SocialSecurityVendorOverrideEst: You can enter a value for your estimated Social Security income at normal retirement age. The estimate will adjust as you move the sliders.  The Windfall Elimination Provision affects how the amount of your Social Security benefit is calculated if you receive a pension from work where Social Security was not taken out of your pay.  If you are subject to the WEP, you can use the WEP calculator on the Social Security website to estimate your benefits.  Enter the estimated monthly amount from the WEP calculator as your estimated Social Security income at normal retirement age.

content.HelpText_SocialSecurityEstimatedMonthlyI:
We can estimate this for you. However if you know this amount, you can enter a value for your estimated income at normal retirement age and we will save it as your normal retirement age value and the estimates in the dollar bill will adjust as you move the sliders. If you would like more help getting that value, you can use the [Quick Calculator] on the Social Security website.

[Quick Calculator]: http://www.socialsecurity.gov/OACT/quickcalc/
content.HelpText_SocialSecurityexpectedRetiremen: Slide to choose the age at which you plan to retire. Updates here will update on the home screen as well.

content.LoanOverlayFE_RetirementIncomeImpacttext: Taking a loan may impact how much money you can earn in your retirement account. Stopping or reducing contributions while you pay the loan back could also make it harder for you to reach your retirement income goals.<br/><br/>If you stop making contributions, your estimated retirement income would <b>decrease by $~~contribdrop~~</b> a month.<br/><br/>
content.LoanOverlayNonFE_MustRepayinFullheader: What are the consequences of not repaying my loan?
content.HelpText_SocialSecurityBeginCollectingAg:
Slide to choose the age at which you plan to start collecting Social Security benefits. Normal retirement age is the age at which you should expect to receive your full benefit. 

* While you can start collecting benefits as early as 62, those benefits will be reduced compared to if you waited until your normal retirement age to collect.


* If you start to collect benefits after your full retirement age and up to age 70, you will receive higher benefits because of additional earnings and credits for delayed retirement.
content.HelpText_StateIplantoretire: Healthcare costs can vary widely by state. Select the state in which you expect to live during your retirement so that we may approximate the local healthcare costs.
content.LoanOverlayNonFE_Considerthesefactsbefor: Taking a loan has financial bumps that may impact your retirement.
content.SocialSecurityNonFE_VariableLanguageForO: You may see an even greater reduction in benefits
content.SocialSecurityNonFE_LanguageModalForOffs:
You can collect Social Security retirement or survivors benefits and work at the same time. But, if you're younger than full retirement age, and your earned income is too high, your benefits will be reduced. The benefits are not lost forever due to the reduction. Your benefit will be recalculated at your full retirement age to account for benefits previously withheld due to earnings. (Spouses and survivors, who receive benefits because they have minor or disabled children in their care don't receive increased benefits at full retirement age if benefits were withheld because of work.) 


**Source: How Work Affects Your Benefits at [http://www.socialsecurity.gov/pubs/EN-05-10069.pdf](http://www.socialsecurity.gov/pubs/EN-05-10069.pdf)**

content.SpecialNeeds_SNDisabilityBenefitsandCons: For more details on your special needs planning, please speak to your Advisor.
content.HelpText_SNGoalHelp:
Because your expenses may change when you stop working, 100% of your 
pre-retirement income may not be required to maintain your standard of living in retirement. For instance, some expenses may go down or go away, such as taxes and work-related expenses, while some may go up, like health care costs and money you spend on new hobbies or activities.
<br /><br />
Your needs may require a different income goal, so you have the opportunity to revise this percentage here or by updating your "About Me" information. Please check back at least once a year to keep your information up to date.
content.HelpText_HealthCareCostatAgeHelp: Slide to the age at which you would like an estimate of healthcare expenses. In general, healthcare related expenses will continue to grow as you get older. This tool assumes retirement at age 65 or older. If you plan to retire before age 65, please explore healthcare options at healthcare.gov.

<br>To review information about the selected retirement system, including the benefit formula, payout options, cost of living adjustment information, employee contribution rates, as well as additional information, click on Retirement System Details button.
